newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippine firms buy U.S. wheat rejected by China.
newsitem.headline: Philippine firms buy U.S. wheat rejected by China.

text.p: Three Philippine firms bought 35,000 tonnes of U.S. soft winter wheat rejected by China at $192 per tonne, including cost and freight, traders said on Wednesday.
Traders said the price was a significant discount to the prevailing $230 per tonne for soft winter wheat.
Earlier reports said American commodity traders offered to sell 70,000 tonnes of U.S. wheat, 35,000 each of soft winter wheat and hard winter wheat, rejected by China to Philippine millers.
The wheat was rejected by China on suspicion the shipments were supposedly tainted with the TCK smut fungus.
Industry executives in the Philippines doubted the latest wheat purchases were fungus-tainted. They said they would not buy wheat they could not use.
"If it's good wheat, and it's something we can use, we will buy," an executive at a local flour mill said.
